Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Intensive Mentored Research Experience for Undergraduates in Clinical, Cognitive, and Behavioral Neuroscience at an Urban Public College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the Neuroscience Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Brooklyn College (BC) is to immerse diverse students in innovative research on clinical, cognitive, and behavioral neuroscience. Twelve students are selected annually for mentored research projects, especially undergraduates at ethnic-minority serving, public two-year and four-year institutions in the New York metropolitan area where the PIs have identified a need for such programming.

Intellectual Merit:

The central component is a semester-long laboratory immersion under the close supervision of BC Psychology Department faculty mentors who have experience working with diverse students, which results in a completed research project. The Department offers a vibrant and highly collaborative research and teaching environment, and the faculty utilizes multiple approaches to understanding brain-behavior relationships. The REU site students are exposed to a variety of behavioral, neuroscientific, and computational methods to address their individual research topics. Students attend a weekly seminar that presents an overview of basic neuroscience principles and domain-specific topics relevant to research conducted in laboratories of core REU faculty. The seminar also address professional issues, including a module on ethics. In addition, students participate in a journal club and attend colloquia in which speakers from outside the Department present cutting-edge neuroscience research and applications. As a capstone experience, students present a poster at the annual Brooklyn College Science Research Day, where they compete with other undergraduates for awards based on the quality of their work and ability to communicate their findings. Some students also have the opportunity to assist in the preparation of a poster for presentation at a national scientific research meeting and/or a peer-reviewed manuscript. The PI team emphasizes the generation of high quality research and integration of psychological theory with the design, execution, and interpretation of neuroscientific data.

Broader Impacts:

This REU site advances neuroscience discovery for the scientific and broader communities while promoting mentoring, learning, and professional development. The specific objectives are to: (1) increase participation of students from underrepresented groups (e.g., women, racial minorities, first-generation college students, veterans returning from active duty) in the field of neuroscience; (2) guide students through the scientific process, from generation of viable research questions to communicating study results; (3) immerse students in relevant didactics that complement their laboratory work and highlight its relevance and applied value; and (4) provide knowledge, skills, and exposure to leading neuroscience research, as well as opportunities for students to make contributions to this research, to enhance their competitiveness for graduate school or professional positions. Strong institutional support from BC of the City University of New York and clearly defined criteria for self-evaluation ensure that the PI team meets their stated goals. Importantly, this REU Program enables BC faculty members to supervise talented undergraduates, who might otherwise miss out on mentored laboratory and professional development experiences, and contribute to the training and advancement of the next generation of neuroscientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For three years (2012-2015), the Neuroscience Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program at Brooklyn College has immersed diverse students in innovative research on clinical, cognitive, and behavioral neuroscience along with professional development experiences (Rabin et al., 2013). We have engaged students in the excitement of scientific discovery while providing critical preparation for graduate study and future professional endeavors. Twelve students were selected annually, especially undergraduates at ethnic-minority serving, public, two- and four-year institutions in the NYC metropolitan area. Table 1 presents REU students’ demographic characteristics aggregated over three years, and Figure 1 shows our 2014 cohort and graduate instructors.

The central component of the REU program involved a semester-long laboratory immersion under the supervision of Brooklyn College Psychology and Biology Department faculty mentors. Students participated in an entire research effort, from inception to project completion, while being exposed to a variety of behavioral, clinical, cognitive, neuroscientific, and computational methods. We emphasized the generation of high-quality research and integration of psychological and neuroscientific theory with the design, execution, and interpretation of data. We also encouraged students to present and publish their results. All 36 REU students presented first-authored posters at the annual Brooklyn College Science Day, where they competed for College-wide, interdepartmental (e.g., Psychology, Biology, Chemistry) awards based on work quality and the ability to communicate findings. Figure 2 displays examples of these poster presentations. Among hundreds of conference presenters, 10 of our 36 REU students received awards (5 third-place, 3 second-place, and 2 first-place). In addition, roughly one-third of REU student-related projects were accepted for presentation at professional conferences or for publication as peer-reviewed manuscripts. Our students received other honors, including Psi Chi Awards at the Annual Meeting of the Eastern Psychological Association and a GEICO Life Scholarship Award by the Golden Key International Honour Society.

REU students also attended weekly seminars, which complemented their laboratory work and highlighted its relevance and applied value. These didactics were instructed by doctoral students and included: (1) a seminar that covered neuroscience principles and research methods along with professional issues and career development; (2) a journal club to familiarize students with the scientific literature in modern neuroscience through learning to select, read, critically analyze, and present summaries of original research papers; and (3) a statistical methods seminar that emphasized data analysis, statistical reasoning, and presentation of findings in academic contexts. Students also attended research talks (on psychology and neuroscience related topics) at Brooklyn College and other local institutions and undertook intensive neuroethics training to enhance knowledge of ethical issues relevant to neuroscience research. Outcome data presented in Figure 3 indicate that REU students augmented their subjective and objective knowledge of neuroscience and research methods over the course of the program (Rabin et al., 2014). Additionally, after undergoing neuroethics training, students demonstrated improved confidence in knowledge, decision-making strategies, and peer-advising ability in research ethics (Walder et al., 2014). Qualitative feedback revealed that the didactics were a worthwhile complement to students’ lab work.
